author: Anna Claire Vollers
title: New exhibit takes art lovers inside the opulent world of the royal Romanovs
text:
Comments This is truly a rare opportunity to see these exquisite and historically important works in our own backyard. 
The ill-fated Romanovs have long been the subject of fascination and speculation. The Romanov tsars ruled Imperial Russia for 200 years before Tsar Nicholas II and his family were murdered by Bolshevik revolutionaries in the early 20 th century,. 
History buffs and art lovers can see treasures from the Romanov era first-hand when a traveling exhibition featuring more than 200 decorative works opens at the Huntsville Museum of Art on Oct. 11. 
"The Tsars' Cabinet: Two Hundred Years of Russian Decorative Arts" is going to be a "blockbuster" exhibition, said HMA Executive Director Christopher Madkour. 
"Bring your family and friends who visit during the holidays," he said, "as this is truly a rare opportunity to see these exquisite and historically important works in our own backyard." 
The exhibit, curated from a private collection, spans the two centuries of Romanov reign, from the time of Peter the Great in the mid-18 th century to the final years of Tsar Nicholas II in the early 20 th century, before his family was ousted and later murdered by Bolshevik revolutionaries. 
Displays will feature examples of Russian porcelain and glassware produced by the Imperial Porcelain Factory and Imperial Glass Factory, as well as Faberge and Ovchinnikov items. Many of the pieces were designed for personal use by the tsars and other Romanovs. 
Rare items include two pieces from a service that Catherine the Great ordered for her grandson, Grand Duke Constantine Pavlovich, and pieces from services presented to the 18 th -century tsarinas by Augustus III of Saxony and Frederick the Great. 
A lecture and reception will open the HMA exhibition on Oct. 17 from 5:30-8 p.m. This event is open to the public and features guest presenter Kathleen Durdin, from whose private collection the exhibition was curated. 
A reception will follow the lecture and will feature Huntsville Symphony Orchestra pianist Curtis Lindsay performing selected Russian music, including music from the film "Doctor Zhivago" and works by Russian composer Dmitry Kabalevsky. White Russian cocktails will be served as well as hors d'oeuvres from Catering by Narvell. Cocktail attire is suggested; tickets are available at www.hsvmuseum.org or by calling (256) 535-4350. 
"The Tsars' Cabinet" will run through Jan. 3, 2016. More information is available at www.hsvmuseum.org.
